entry.title: Revealing Jekyll
entry.content:
As a Beamer alternative, I have been wanting to look into the Reveal.js presentation framework for sometime. Also, I thought it would be a nice way of spicing up some blog posts with a flashcard effect. To this end, we will cover how to configure and integrate the Reveal.js framework within your Jekyll site.

Contents

  • Loading Reveal.js
  • Embedding Slide Shows
  • Indexing Slide Decks
  • For the Road

Loading Reveal.js

    To integrate Reveal.js with Jekyll, we will need a copy of the framework within your site’s root directory.

$ wget https://github.com/hakimel/reveal.js/archive/master.zip
$ unzip master.zip -d ./reveal.js
$ rm master.zip

Or you can git clone the framework.

$ git clone https://github.com/hakimel/reveal.js
$ rm -r reveal.js/.git

Indexing Slide Decks

For the Road

    With Reveal.js, we can create polished slide decks. By combining Reveal.js with Jekyll, we can host presentations with our site. The Reveal.js project README provides a complete overview of the Reveal.js framework, including details for speaker notes and presentation multiplexing. Also, see the links below for example presentations and plugins.

entry.title: \(\rm\LaTeX\) in Jekyll
entry.content:
Among other topics, the plan is to post on mathematics concepts I am trying to grasp. Nothing consolidates your understanding like working things out on paper the keyboard. So, it is time to cover some of Jekyll’s support for \(\rm\LaTeX\). MathJax will allow us to display mathematics. We can also incorporate \(\rm{B\scriptsize IB}\TeX\) references using Jekyll-Scholar.

Contents

  • \(\rm\LaTeX\) with MathJax
  • \(\rm{B\scriptsize IB}\TeX\) with Jekyll-Scholar
  • Pushing to GitHub
  • For the Road

\(\rm\LaTeX\) with MathJax

    MathJax is a JavaScript engine for typesetting mathematics in web browsers. To use MathJax within Jekyll, we can append the following script to the HTML head or body.

Now we can display mathematics using escaped parentheses and brackets. Inline equations, such as \(G = 8\pi T\), can be rendered like so:

Displayed equations, \[\Lambda f = \int_X f\ \rm{d}\mu\] for example, are another option:

    It is also possible to display commutative diagrams. This requires an additional configuration script prior to loading MathJax in the head or body.

Here is an example diagram: \[ \begin{CD} \pi_{k}\left(X,A,x_0\right) @>h_\bullet>> \pi_{k}\left(Y,B,y_0\right) \\ @V{\varphi}VV @V{\varphi}VV \\ H_{k}\left(X,A\right) @>h_\bullet>> H_{k}\left(Y,B\right) \end{CD} \] Diagrams must be enclosed in a CD environment:

Now we can typeset all the math we kind of know.

\(\rm{B\scriptsize IB}\TeX\) with Jekyll-Scholar

    We can also handle \(\rm{B\scriptsize IB}\TeX\) references with the help of Jekyll-Scholar. We will need to have Jekyll-Scholar installed.

Next, we will add the gem to our Gemfile.

Assuming our bibliography appears in _bibliography/references.bib relative to the site source directory, here is a sample configuration which will appear in your _config.yml:

    Now, we can display a test inline citation [1]. This is rendered with the Liquid cite tag and the desired \(\rm{B\scriptsize IB}\TeX\) key.

The bibliography tag will display your bibliography.

    We can also customize the layout of the bibliography. As an example, create a file with the path _layouts/bib.html containing the following snippet:

Then add the next snippet to the Jekyll-Scholar configuration in _config.yml.

To finish, we will need to add some JavaScript with a file called assets/javascript/toggle.js:

Here is a test bibliography:

  1. “LaTeX in Jekyll.” 2018 [Online]. Available at: https://sdleisure.github.io/jekyll/latex/2018/04/03/latex-in-jekyll.html
    • Access
    • BibTex
      • @misc{Foo,
  title = {LaTeX in Jekyll},
  type = {Website},
  year = {2018},
  url = {https://sdleisure.github.io/jekyll/latex/2018/04/03/latex-in-jekyll.html},
  note = {Accessed: 2018-04-03}
}

Pushing to GitHub

    By way of security policy, GitHub runs only a select few plugins. Thus, we must push our locally generated site to GitHub if we want to utilize the Jekyll-Scholar plugin. For what follows, we assume a develop branch exists in the local Git repository.

$ git branch develop

After generating your Jekyll site, the contents of the _site directory must be pushed to GitHub using a site branch.

$ git checkout develop
$ bundler exec jekyll build
$ git add -A && git commit -m 'Generated site'
$ git checkout -b site
$ git filter-branch --prune-empty --subdirectory-filter _site/ site
$ git remote add origin https://github.com/user/repo
$ git push origin site:master

When editing the develop branch, the changes must be added to the site branch and pushed.

$ git checkout develop
$ # Making some changes.
$ bundler exec jekyll build
$ git add -A && git commit -m 'Committing changes'
$ git checkout site
$ git reset --hard refs/heads/develop
$ git filter-branch -f --prune-empty --subdirectory-filter _site/ site
$ git push origin site:master

For the Road

    Using MathJax, we can begin displaying mathematics in our posts. Regardless of our bias towards \(\rm\LaTeX\), MathJax offers support for MathML and AsciiMath as well. The MathJax API also provides support for dynamic sites. We urge the reader to see the links below for more information and access to plenty of helpful extensions.

  • MathJax Documentation
  • MathJax CDN
  • \(\rm\LaTeX\) Reference Manual
  • \(\rm\LaTeX\) Symbol List

entry.title: Snippet Cosmetics in Jekyll
entry.content:
After tailoring Rouge for my Jekyll site, a memorandum is due. Rouge is a syntax highlighter written in Ruby. As of Jekyll 3, it is the default replacing the Pygments highlighter. It can greatly elevate the display and readability of your code snippets if properly leveraged. What I mean to say is your code can look good even if it stinks.

Contents

  • Jekyll Configuration
  • Code Highlighting
  • Handling Box Overflows
  • For the Road

Jekyll Configuration

    Rogue is the built-in code highlighter for Jekyll 3. If you have strayed from the default, you will need to make sure Rouge is installed. A compatible Markdown engine is also required.

$ sudo gem install kramdown rouge

You can then set Rouge as the highlighter in your _config.yml file.

    Rouge is shipped with the rougify command line utility. The rougify command allows you to set the display theme of your code snippets. First take a look at the available themes.

$ rougify help style

To use a particular style, use rougify to create a style sheet and add it to the assets of your site source directory.

$ rougify style foobar > assets/css/highlight.css

Then add a link element to the HTML head.

Code Highlighting

    With Rouge configured, we can start rendering our code blocks. Rouge supports many languages. Enter the following for a list of supported languages:

$ rougify list

Code snippets can be created with Markdown.

#include <iostream>

int main() {
  std::cout << "Hello World!";
}

Alternatively, Liquid can be used.

public class HelloWorld {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    System.out.println("Hello World!");
  }
}

Liquid can also include line numbers with the linenos argument.

Handling Box Overflows

    Box overflows can be handled with an extra declaration block in the Rouge theme style sheet. From above, recall the style sheet has the path assets/css/highlight.css relative to your site source directory. The following block specifies overflows to be clipped and a scrolling feature added.

From my experience, it might be necessary to add some padding for snippets with line numbers. A block similar to the following snippet should work.

For the Road

    Now that we have Rouge highlighting our snippets, code readability will be improved. This serves me well considering my high turnover memory. Rouge offers support for many languages. Take a look at the documentation for a listing.

  • Rouge Documentation

entry.title: Minima(l) Jekyll Setup
entry.content:
Given this is my first Jekyll site, it seems appropriate to cover its basic setup and deployment to GitHub Pages. GitHub Pages is a hosting service for static site generators. A static website is a good choice if you have no need for client input or if you are a simpleton new to web design, like me. Quick remark: the sequel will have a Debian flavor.

Contents

  • Installing Git
  • Installing Jekyll
  • Creating the Site
  • Deploying the Site
  • For the Road

Installing Git

    First off, we are going to need Git. If you have not already installed it, you can personalize the following:

$ sudo apt-get -y install git-all
$ git config --global user.name "Foo Bar"
$ git config --global user.email baz@qux.com
$ git config --global core.editor foobar

The core.editor variable allows you to set your preferred editor, for example, Vim or Emacs. If unset, the system’s default editor will be used. Git can also summarize your configuration.

$ git config --list

Installing Jekyll

    Before we can generate our Jekyll site, we must have Ruby installed.

$ sudo apt-get update
$ sudo apt-get -y install ruby ruby-dev make gcc

We can now install Jekyll and the Ruby gems dependency manager Bundler.

$ sudo gem install jekyll bundler

Creating the Site

    As it turns out, building a Jekyll site with the Minima theme is super hard.

$ jekyll new mysite && cd mysite
$ git init
$ jekyll build
$ git add . && git commit -m "Initial page commit."

The next snippet allows you a local glimpse of your site by browsing to http://localhost:4000.

$ bundler exec jekyll serve --watch >/dev/null 2>&1 &

The --watch switch performs an auto-regeneration as you locally edit your site.

    It is worth mentioning you can keep your local Jekyll environment in order with that of GitHub Pages. In your site’s Gemfile, just replace the line which contains gem "jekyll" with the following line:

Run bundler install to finish. Do not forget to keep your locale in sync.

$ sudo bundler update github-pages

Deploying the Site

    The time has come to deploy our site to GitHub. Make sure you have created the necessary repositories on GitHub. You can publish a User Page as follows:

$ git checkout master
$ git remote add origin https://github.com/username/username.github.io
$ git push -u origin master

Now, your User Page will be hosted at https://username.github.io.

    You can also publish a Project Page with the gh-pages branch.

$ git branch -m master gh-pages
$ git remote add origin https://github.com/username/repo
$ git push -u origin gh-pages

You Project Page will appear at https://username.github.io/repo. Separating your site from your project source files can be done with an orphan branch.

$ git checkout --orphan gh-pages
$ git remote add origin https://github.com/username/repo
$ git push -u origin gh-pages

At long last, your site should be up for someone everyone to see.

For the Road

    So, now we know how to set up a basic Jekyll site on GitHub. For those of us looking to be initiated in web development, Jekyll is a safe option. Relying on Markdown and Liquid, Jekyll provides a minimal approach to static site generation. Here are some links to help us build vocabulary and add some zest to our basic Jekyll site.

  • DevDocs
  • Writing on GitHub
  • Jekyll Docs
  • Jekyll Themes
  • kramdown Syntax
  • Liquid Reference
  • Markdown Reference
  • SCSS Reference
  • Supported GitHub Pages Themes
  • YAML Reference
